@s-azumi

The twist_gate node throws the topic `/state_cmd` with `emergency` key, and then the decision_maker state transitions to the `Emergency` state.
After that, when you restart the decision_maker node, the "emergency" command is latched and the state transitions to "Emergency" immediately.

comment_text: Well spotted. I have removed it, thanks.
@esteve Should this be `drivers/streetdrone`?

@gbiggs not sure, on the one hand yes it's the driver for SD's vehicle interface. However, it's so vehicle-specific and their repository may contain other related packages in the future (e.g. URDF model, simulation worlds, etc.) that I suggested @EfimiaPanagiotaki-StreetDrone to put it in `vehicles/sd`. This is akin to OpenEmbedded, where they have drivers for each component, and then the BSP packages that aggregate the drivers and add configurations.
Works for me. :+1:
@EfimiaPanagiotaki-StreetDrone could you tag this? It'll be easier to track bugs if the users can tell us what version of the interface they are using. Thanks!
This is for the master of Autoware. Do we want to allow the master of Autoware to also use the master of its dependencies, or do we want to always depend on an explicit version?
This has the problem that if a pull request does not change the contents of autoware.repos, the master branches will be fetched.
You could copy the original directory (`$CI_PROJECT_DIR`) over, so that the files that are tested are the ones from the pull request.

comment_text: The lgvsl_msgs package was released into the ROS buildfarm (https://index.ros.org/r/lgsvl_msgs/github-lgsvl-lgsvl_msgs/), so we no longer need to add it here.

pull_request_title: Add .repos file for setting up an Autoware workspace using vcs
comment_text: That's the goal, although something that needs to be discussed is whether project-wide documentation should be in this repo or its own. ROS 2 uses a dedicated repo, and currently that's what I've set up. That's the need for the checkout. If we decide to stick with documentation in its own repository, I'll remove it.

pull_request_title: Add .repos file for setting up an Autoware workspace using vcs
comment_text:
Alas, I didn't even think about it when I used the *correct* English spelling. :wink:

The Japanese use <strike>Wrong</strike>American English spelling, and we have many users in the USA, so maybe that's the way to go. I don't want to waste time choosing the language for the bike shed signs, so I'm just going to go with that. It will give us consistency with ROS, too.

You have changed from gibibytes to gigabytes. Please explain why.

Because Ubuntu directly show data size in gigabytes. If we use gibibytes, it will lead to inconsistent  of our input and recorded data size showed by Ubuntu, like we set split size as 20GB but obtain a 21.5GB data. 
Some user report this issue to us, and say they are confused by this. So we decide to change to  gigabytes.
Your PR description does not mention that at all. Please update the description to state what you have actually changed and why.

you are probably going to hate me but, can you please move all your includes to `/include/lidar_point_pillars/`

You'll need to change your includes to prefix `lidar_point_pillars/` in all your sources includes.

If I'm not clear enough:
Currently you have this
```
├── include
│   ├── anchor_mask_cuda.h
│   ├── common.h
│   ├── nms_cuda.h
│   ├── point_pillars.h
│   ├── point_pillars_ros.h
│   ├── postprocess_cuda.h
│   ├── preprocess_points_cuda.h
│   ├── preprocess_points.h
│   └── scatter_cuda.h
```

Change it to:
```
├── include
│   └── lidar_point_pillars
│            ├── anchor_mask_cuda.h
│            ├── common.h
│            ├── nms_cuda.h
│            ├── point_pillars.h
│            ├── point_pillars_ros.h
│            ├── postprocess_cuda.h
│            ├── preprocess_points_cuda.h
│            ├── preprocess_points.h
│            └── scatter_cuda.h
```
and update your source files, adding the `lidar_point_pillars` prefix:
i.e.
```
--- a/ros/src/computing/perception/detection/lidar_detector/packages/lidar_point_pillars/nodes/anchor_mask_cuda.cu
+++ b/ros/src/computing/perception/detection/lidar_detector/packages/lidar_point_pillars/nodes/anchor_mask_cuda.cu
@@ -16,7 +16,7 @@
 
 //headers in local files
-#include "anchor_mask_cuda.h"
+#include "lidar_point_pillars/anchor_mask_cuda.h"
```

Finally, change the install command to 
```
         DESTINATION ${CATKIN_PACKAGE_INCLUDE_DESTINATION}/lidar_point_pillars
```

why not use a const instead of 2*4 ?

In CUDA, even the const variable is considered as runtime changeable variable, plus it is not allowed to have array with changeable size inside the kernel.

@gbiggs @esteve @kfunaoka this package uses a pre-trained network that is not for commercial purposes. 

I think that we need to find a way to clearly mark such packages, otherwise it will be difficult to find them later and it will also cause confusion with Autoware users trying to commercialize such packages.

Yes, I agree. I'll add it to my notes for the documentation template.

I think we also need a way for a user to easily select between using a non-commercial pre-trained network that we provide and a network they provide themselves (as well as a good method and documentation for how to train a network). This would improve the usefulness of Autoware without placing a burden on us to provide trained networks. I'll add *this* to my increasing pile of notes on what Autoware should be. :)

Many packages (like ros-${ROS2_DISTRO}-ament-cmake) depend on many of the packages below. Even with --no-install-recommends, it should still automatically install the dependencies. Is it required for some reason to list them out below if they are dependencies of another package? ament-cmake covers -core, -export-definitions, -export-dependencies, -export-include-directories, -export-libraries, -export-link-flags, -libraries, -python, -target-dependencies, -test, and -workspace.

Is there a reason for this change? The ha pool isn't listed here: https://sks-keyservers.net/overview-of-pools.php and, since we are using port 80 to avoid Dockerhub restrictions, doesn't p80 make more sense?

@JWhitleyAStuff I think it is very useful for clarity of what we do here. These packages (and ROS2 in parallel with ROS1) are just a temporary solution to facilitate the transition to ROS2 and will go away once ROS_DISTRO becomes crystal. However at the moment it is nice to have it here listed in the most explicit way.
Noted, thank you! However it comes from #1982 - I'll mention it there.

I'd advise against using rosdep here as it prevents Docker from using the cache effectively. There's also no trace of what packages are being installed, and more importantly, given that ROS1 does not guarantee ABI compatibility, any  ROS package installed afterwards may cause a segfault.

The previous Dockerfile had a list of ROS packages being installed. They were not comprehensive and were very likely to be out of sync as the dependencies change from version to version.

The rationale for doing it like this was that for a given version of Autoware, its corresponding Docker base image will have the dependencies pre-installed. If you are using this based to develop new features, then you will have to manually run rosdep again to complement the new dependencies required.

The effect on Docker's cache could be minimised with a list, but the cache would still be discarded eventually when the list gets updated. It is a trade-off between getting the dependencies automatically sorted out (instead of someone manually finding them out and updating the Dockerfile) vs increasing the usage of cache.
What do you think would be a better balance? Perhaps splitting ros-desktop-full and a few other basic ROS packages out into their own RUN command to at least re-use that layer? Move the rosdep step to be part of the build steps?

I'm not sure I understand the compatibility issue. Aren't these all deb packages which are meant to be compatible on the same distro?

> What do you think would be a better balance? Perhaps splitting ros-desktop-full and a few other basic ROS packages out into their own RUN command to at least re-use that layer? Move the rosdep step to be part of the build steps?

I think having a list of known packages and then running rosdep install is a good compromise. OSRF has the process entirely automated in their images, perhaps in the future we could just have a script that runs rosdep install and if there are any new packages, add them to Dockerfile and commit the changes.

> I'm not sure I understand the compatibility issue. Aren't these all deb packages which are meant to be compatible on the same distro?

Unfortunately not. If I have packages installed from a previous sync and I install new ones, they are most certainly to crash because they are not ABI-compatible. ROS releases must be upgraded/installed all at once, you can't mix packages from different syncs, even if they are from the same distribution.
Just a correction, it's not certain as I stated, but there's a chance that the packages are incompatible.
